title: Bringing health insurance to small businesses
summary: Product discovery and launch of a new healthcare insurance product for UK SMEs.
outcomes: Validated appetite and pricing signals with target SMEs
Defined MVP enrolment and renewal journeys
Aligned underwriting, sales, and ops on a single service blueprint

sections.title: Design Challenge
body: Imagine this: You're a self-employed courier. It's raining, traffic is heavy, and orders are stacking up in your app. You're navigating buses and taxis to make the next drop.
If you don't ride, you don't earn.
Your bike insurance and liability cover are sorted. But health insurance? It feels corporate, complex, and built for HR departments, not a one-person business powered by an app and a backpack.
sections.leadIn: Simply Business saw health insurance as a growth opportunity. But before building anything, our product discovery unit had to answer one question:
identifiedItems: Would small businesses like this actually want it, and trust us to provide it?

sections.title: Action Taken
body: Recognising our team's limited experience in the health sector, our first step was to gather extensive insights through a combination of qualitative and quantitative research. This involved:

paragraphs: This gave us clarity on: willingness to pay, most valued benefits, language preferences, and trust in Simply Business as a provider.
We then identified and prioritised the riskiest assumptions: Could we offer the right product? Would customers trust us to sell it?
Instead of debating internally, we tested.
Brand vs Value Testing: Users consistently chose better benefits over bigger brand names.
Language Testing: Plain, issue-focused language outperformed medical jargon.
These insights shaped our positioning and product framing early — before any engineering investment.

We increased fidelity and exposure in stages: clickable prototype testing, live demand test in the quote journey (~2,000 weekly visits), and dedicated marketing page + PPC campaign (10,000+ weekly visits).
Each phase validated real customer interest.
By the end of testing, we had strong evidence that health insurance was a viable vertical.

sections.title: Turned assumptions into experiments
sections.leadIn: We identified the two riskiest assumptions:
identifiedItems: We can offer the right product for small business needs
Customers would trust and buy health insurance through Simply Business
bodyEnd: We ran rapid, low-fidelity experiments before committing engineering effort.
Participants chose better value over stronger brand recognition.
Issue-focused, plain English messaging consistently outperformed medical jargon.
These experiments reframed our design principles:
Prioritise tangible value over brand signalling
Reduce cognitive load in a complex category

sections.title: Discovery
body: Interviewed founders and HR leads to map expectations around coverage, price, and setup time.
Mapped service blueprint spanning quote, onboarding, benefits communication, and renewals.

sections.title: Design & validation
body: Designed a guided quote flow with clarity on coverage and a no-surprises checkout.
Created lightweight admin for brokers to manage cohorts and renewals.
Ran moderated tests to compare appetite between bundled and modular benefits.

sections.title: Delivery
body: Documented decision playbooks for underwriting and service teams.
Established a content system for policy clarity and zero-jargon summaries.
